feedback.p: Incorrect. Equilibrium is a term that means that everything is equal. In fact, things in the body are constantly changing, but generally within appropriate limits.
Correct. Relatively stable indicates that most of the time, values of the variables are near the set point, and if they vary, they don’t do so enough to cause dysfunction.

Although homeostasis is most commonly carried out by the many feedback loops, homeostasis is more about the general maintenance of stable conditions rather than the specifics of how that maintenance occurs.
Incorrect. Homeostasis maintains processes of the body.

body.p: You would expect homeostasis to occur at what level(s)?

feedback.p: Incorrect. Although homeostasis is maintained at this level, for example many enzymatic pathways have some level of regulation, this is not the best answer for this question.
> Incorrect. Although homeostasis is maintained at this level, for example cell metabolism and mitosis is typically regulated, this is not the best answer for this question.
Incorrect. Although homeostasis is maintained at this level, for example multiple organs work together to regulate blood glucose, this is not the best answer for this question.
Correct. With a constant influx of new material and changes in environmental conditions, the body works at every level to maintain homeostasis.

body.p: Which of the following would not be considered part of a homeostatic feedback loop for regulating blood plasma calcium concentration?

input.choice: hormones sending messages to various organs
kidneys reabsorbing calcium from the filtrate instead of excreting it in urine.
moving calcium from the skeletal system into the plasma

feedback.p: Incorrect. Hormones often help regulate homeostasis.
Incorrect. The conservation of calcium (usually by hormonal regulation of the kidneys) helps maintain homeostasis.

Correct. This may be confusing, since ingestion can increase the calcium in the body, but there is no internal process of the body that changes ingestion. Most people don’t “crave” calcium products, even if their calcium levels are low. However, regulatory molecules can increase the absorption of calcium in the digestive tract.
Incorrect. Hormonal regulation of bone calcium is the primary mechanism for maintaining blood calcium homeostasis.

body.p: Which feedback mechanism is most commonly used to maintain homeostasis?

input.choice: both positive feedback and negative feedback are used equally
neither positive feedback and negative feedback is used

feedback.p: Correct. Negative feedback most commonly helps in maintaining homeostasis. As one example, when we are cold, we shiver to increase our temperature. That’s negative feedback: our body responds to oppose the decreased body temperature by increasing heat generation.
Incorrect. Positive feedbackcycles occasionally occur in normal physiological systems, but they do so in a limited manner, and are not considered a common mechanism.
Incorrect. While both positive and negative feedback are used to maintain homeostasis, but one occurs more commonly.
Incorrect. Both positive and feedback are used, but one occurs more commonly.

body.p: Which of the following would be an example of a positive feedback mechanism?

input.choice: only pathological (or disease) processes have positive feedback
cervical pressure during the childbirth process

feedback.p: Incorrect. When blood glucose levels increase or decrease away from the set point, effectors work to bring it back toward the normal set point, which is an example of negative feedback.
Incorrect. When blood pressure increases or decreases away from the set point, effectors work to bring it back toward the set point, which is an example of negative feedback.
Incorrect. Although some pathological conditions can include positive feedback cycles, there are also some examples of these in regulating healthy physiologic processes.

Correct. During birthing, pressure on the cervix stimulates stretch receptors and causes the effector (uterus smooth muscle) to contract and put more pressure on the cervix for childbirth. This “self-amplifying cycle is an example of positive feedback.

body.p: What would happen if positive feedback were used in the cruise control system in a car?

input.choice: you would speed up until the engine failed or you would slow down until you stopped
you would maintain a constant speed
you would stop and go alternately

feedback.p: Correct. Cruise control usually works via negative feedback to keep a car moving at a constant speed. However, with positive feedback, an increase in speed would cause the cruise control to further increase speed until the engine failed. Similarly, a decrease in speed would cause the cruise control to slow the car down until it stopped if positive feedback were in effect.
Incorrect. Cruise control usually works via negative feedback to keep a car moving at a constant speed. A positive feedback system would respond very differently.
Incorrect. Both positive and negative feedback usually occur as a process or series of small steps, not abrupt changes.
Incorrect. One of these would occur if the cruise control worked as a positive feedback mechanism.

content.p: Consider the following feedback cycle involving platelets and clotting.

When a blood vessel is injured, platelets adhere to the injured area. These platelets become “activated”, allowing them to adhere to each other in a mass called the platelet plug. They also release several chemicals, including one called thromboxane that causes other platelets to become activated.

multiple_choice.body: This scenario will most likely lead to what?

input.choice: more and more platelets sticking together until something stops the cycle
the platelet plug will continually reduce in size until it is no longer there
the bleeding will continually get worse

response.feedback: Correct. Positive feedback will continue to amplify the effect until something stops the cycle. Eventually, a blockage of flow prevents any more platelets from reaching the area of the platelet plu.
Incorrect. That would happen if this were a negative feedback cycle, but then the plug would not be able to prevent blood loss.
Incorrect. The formation of the platelet plug in this positive feedback mechanism decreases blood loss.
Incorrect. The platelets are transported in plasma in an inactive form, but the chemical being released in this positive feedback mechanism activates them.

multiple_choice.body: What would best represent the variable in the feedback cycle?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Platelets would most likely represent the sensor, control center, and effector in this cycle.
Correct. It is a break in the integrity of the blood vessel that initiates the positive feedback mechanism.
Incorrect. Thromboxane is the method of communication between platelets.
Incorrect. The size of the platelet plug is not directly monitored to influence the cycle.

no_response.feedback: You did not submit an answer.

multiple_choice.body: What is a potential medical problem associated with formation of the platelet plug?

response.feedback: Correct. Atherosclerosis (plaque development) of vessels can sometimes initiate platelet plug formation, which can lead to a complete vessel occlusion, leading to a heart attack or stroke.
Incorrect. The platelet plug counteracts blood loss.

Incorrect. Although platelets are consumed during the process, formation of the platelet plug typically ceases prior to using up too many platelets and the body will produce more platelets by a negative feedback mechanism.
Incorrect. This cycle limits vascular damage and initiate the healing process.

multiple_choice.body: Aspirin reduces the ability of platelets to produce thromboxane. How does this affect the feedback cycle?

input.choice: it changes the level of the variable being monitored
it reduces the number of effectors in the cycle
it interrupts the method of communication between platelets
it prevents the sensor from detecting a change in the variable

response.feedback: Incorrect. Aspirin limits the cycle, but deosn't interrupt the cycle completely or affect the variable directly.
Incorrect. It does not change the platelet numbers, but it does affect the response of the platelets.
Correct. Thromboxane is used as a method of communication amoung platelets. Aspiring decreases the amount of thromboxane made, limiting activation of more platelets.
Incorrect. Platelets can still detect changes in the integrity of the vessel.

content.p: To regulate body fluid osmolarity (concentration of solutes in body fluids), osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus monitor this. The hypothalamus will stimulate the posterior pituitary to release the hormone ADH when the plasma osmolarity increases. ADH causes the kidney to retain more water, reducing urine output.
Match the parts of this feedback loop with the correct terminology.

Incorrect. The receptor is specifically monitoring the variable.
Correct. The hypothalamus determines if the osmolarity of body fluids is at the set point or if it is above or below.
Incorrect. The effector would initiate a change in the variable based on communication from the control center.

multiple_choice.body: Which of these other organ systems is not part of the feedback loop described, but would also likely contribute to homeostasis of body fluid osmolarity?

response.feedback: Correct. The digestive system absorbs and/or excretes water and solutes, which can help contribute to a stable body fluid environment.

Incorrect. In some ways the movement of the muscular system can generate heat and may cause a slight loss of water and salts in sweat, but this is an indirect side-effect of a homeostasis mechanisms for a different variable.
Incorrect. The skeletal system is responsible for support and has little effect on body fluid osmolarity.

Incorrect. The humidified air that we exhale does cause some loss of water, but this is not something that can be easily regulated, so this system does not generally contribute to maintenance of body fluid osmolarity.

body.p: Heart rate commonly changes in response to challenges to the body, yet there is no direct sensor for heart rate. This would suggest that heart rate is:

input.choice: An input signal to the control center
A communication from the control center

feedback.p: Incorrect. There would need to be a receptor monitoring heart rate for there to be input about this change.
Incorrect. The heart is not the control center, so this isn’t an appropriate choice here.

Correct. Heart rate is a response of the effector (heart) to change blood pressure. Under normal conditions, if heart rate increases, the blood pressure also increases. If heart rate decreases, blood pressure also decreases.
Incorrect. The control center will communicate with the heart (effector) by chemical or nerve impulse to initiate this response.

body.p: Which of the following is a control center for the regulation of plasma calcium levels in adults?

feedback.p: Incorrect. The hypothalamus is a control center for many of the homeostatic feedbacks, but not in this case.
Correct. Plasma calcium levels are regulated by the endocrine system, mainly the parathyroid gland.
Incorrect. The pancreas is involved in blood glucose homeostasis, not blood calcium levels.
Incorrect. The kidneys would be one of the effectors involved in blood calcium levels, not the control center.

body.p: Which of the following analogies best describes negative feedback homeostasis?

input.choice: When you apply the brakes on a car and it slows down.
When you turn the key in the ignition and the car starts.
When cruise control is used to maintain the speed of the car, even on hilly terrain.
When the car burns fuel to produce torque.

feedback.p: Incorrect. This would be a change in the variable (car speed), but it is not due to input from a sensor nor a response able to maintain car speed near the set point.
Incorrect. This would be necessary for movement of the car, but has nothing to do with monitoring or maintaining the speed of the car.
Correct. If your car is on cruise control, the sensor provides input so it can automatically speed up or slow down to maintain the set speed.
Incorrect. This would be necessary for movement of the car, but has nothing to do with monitoring or maintaining the speed of the car.

body.p: The main benefit of using negative feedback instead of positive feedback to control a variable is that:

input.choice: Negative feedback can respond more rapidly.
Negative feedback doesn’t require the use of nerves.
Negative feedback brings the variable back toward the set point.
Negative feedback uses a sensor, control center and effector(s).

feedback.p: Incorrect. Both types of feedback have the potential to react rapidly.
Incorrect. Many negative feedback loops use nerves to communicate information.
Correct. Negative feedback brings the body back toward its set point rather than moving it further from it by enhancing the variable change.
Incorrect. Both types of feedback use all these components.

body.p: An example of positive feedback is:

input.choice: The platelet aggregation aspect of hemostasis.

feedback.p: Incorrect. This is an example of negative feedback maintained near a set point, with increase or decrease of blood plasma glucose as necessary.
Incorrect.
Correct. A positive feedback cycle contributes to the formation of the platelet plug (aggregation).
Incorrect. This is an example of negative feedback maintained near a set point, with increase or decrease of blood plasma osmolarity as necessary.
